title: Dennis Skinner delivers Queen's Speech zinger in withering putdown to Black Rod
text:
The video will start in 8 Cancel

Get the biggest politics stories by email Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email

Dennis Skinner has delivered his classic Queen's Speech zinger by shouting out "I'm not going" when the Queen's representative Black Rod asked MPs to go to the House of Lords.

The Republican 'Beast of Bolsover' is known for shouting at the representative as a show of disrespect - and today was no different.

Lords messenger Black Rod - in ceremonial garb - traditionally knocks on for MPs on the Commons chamber door, and has it slammed in her face.

This year when told that the Queen requested the MPs' presence, Mr Skinner yelled out that he didn't want to go with laughter echoing round the chamber.

It could also be interpreted as the 87-year-old's refusal to quit as an MP.

Mr Skinner's famed barbs have been a tradition for more than 30 years, fired from his usual front-row seat.

At the end of Margaret Thatcher's power he shouted “It tolls for thee, Maggie” while another time he scoffed "here comes Puss in Boots!"

(Image: POOL/AFP via Getty Images)

He failed to deliver at the 2015 State Opening of Parliament - complaining new SNP members had stolen his usual seat.

The last speech was delayed by two days as Theresa May struggled to pull together a deal with Northern Ireland's DUP to keep herself in power.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

That meant the Queen was forced to miss a morning of Royal Ascot , one of her favourite events of the year.

That time Mr Skinner shouted: "Get your skates on, first race is at half past two!"

Here's a look at the best of the Beast of Bolsover's witty zingers.

(Image: POOL/AFP via Getty Images)

A rundown of putdowns

1987 “Tell her to sell up!”

An appeal to the Queen as the country went through a tough time

1988 “Hey up, here comes Puss in Boots!"

1989 “It’s a good outfit!”

Two special lines for Black Rod

1990 “It tolls for thee, Maggie”

As Thatcher faced the exit from Number 10

(Image: DM)

1991 “I bet he drinks Carling Black Label!”

Famous lager slogan delivered just for Black Rod

1992 “Tell her to pay her taxes”

(Image: Keystone/Hulton Archive/Getty Images)

After the Commons debated whether the Queen should pay tax

1993 “Back to basics with Black Rod”

The Tories famous slogan gets the Skinner treatment

1996 “New Labour, New Black Rod”

And another famous catchphrase gets reworked

2000 “Tell her to read The Guardian”

(Image: Keystone/Hulton Archive/Getty Images)

Skinner gives his backing to the paper's call to make Britain a republic…

2001 “You’re nowt but a midget!”

The new Black Rod, Michael Willocks, gets a warm welcome from Dennis

2003 “Did she lock the door behind her?”

Buckingham Palace had been the subject of a string of break-ins

(Image: DM)

2006 “Have you got Helen Mirren on standby?”

Dame Helen had just starred in the critically-acclaimned 'The Queen'

2007 “Who shot the harriers?"

Prince Harry and a pal had just been questioned after two hen harriers were shot dead at Sandringham

2008 “Any Tory moles at the palace?”

Tory MP Damian Green had just been arrested as part of an inquiry into Home Office leaks

2009 “Royal expenses are on the way”

Dennis tries to turn the tables as Parliament is engulfed by the expenses scandal

2012 “Jubilee Year, double-dip recession, what a start!”

This remark brought a mixture of outright laughter and jeers. But mostly laughter.

2013 "Royal Mail for sale. Queen's head privatised."

(Image: Paliament.tv)

Reference to the planned privatisation of Royal Mail.

(Image: PRU/AFP via Getty Images)

2014 "Coalition's last stand."

Much laughter as Dennis points out there are just 11 months to go until the election

2015 No jibe

He failed to make a quip because he said he had been too busy battling Scottish nationalists over his favourite seat in the House of Commons.

2016 "Hands off the BBC!"

A demand to save the Corporation from doom after stars warned "blink and it will be gone".

2017 "Get your skates on, first race is at half past two!"
description: The Bolsover MP shouted out "I'm not going" to loud laugher in the House of Commons
